[[File:Paderborner Dom Dreihasenfenster.jpg|thumb|Dreihasenfenster (Window of Three Hares) in [[Paderborn Cathedral]]]]
The '''three hares''' (or '''three rabbits''') is a circular [[motif (visual arts)|motif]] or [[meme]] appearing in [[sacred sites]] from the Middle and Far East to the churches of [[Devon]], England (as the "[[Dartmoor tin-mining|Tinners]]' Rabbits"),<ref name="Chapman">{{cite web | url=http://www.chrischapmanphotography.co.uk/hares/index.html | title=The Three Hares Project | author=Chapman, Chris | year=2004 | accessdate=2013-10-21}}</ref> and historical synagogues in Europe.<ref name="Wonnenberg">{{cite web |url=http://felice.naomi.googlepages.com/videosandfilms3 |title=How do the rabbits get into the synagogue? From China via Middle East and Germany to Galizia: On the tracks of the ROTATING RABBITS SYMBOL |last1=Wonnenberg |first1=Felice Naomi |publisher=googlepages.com |accessdate=2011-08-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67Aj1hC3c?url=http://sites.google.com/site/felicenaomi/videosandfilms |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> It is used as an architectural [[Bronze and brass ornamental work|ornament]], a religious [[Iconography|symbol]], and in other modern [[works of art]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finestoneminiatures.com/catalog/catalog_97.htm |title=Miniature sculptures of Tinners' Rabbits, ca. 1300) |publisher=Finestoneminiatures.com |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artmatters.org.uk/galleries/bronze/pages/Tinners%20Rabbit.htm |title=Tinner's Rabbits sculpture, Art that Matters |publisher=Artmatters.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703183947/http://www.artmatters.org.uk/galleries/bronze/pages/Tinners%20Rabbit.htm |archivedate=3 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> or a logo for [[adornment]] (including [[tattoos]]),<ref>[[Celtic knot]] [http://wildspiritwolf.deviantart.com/art/Triple-Hare-Celtic-Tattoo-153039183 Tattoo: border encircling Triple knotwork Hares by "WildSpiritWolf".]</ref> [[jewelry]], and a [[coat of arms]] on an [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]].<ref>The "three hares motif from a window of the Paderborn cathedral cloister (Unity and Trinity as a symbol of the Trinity, the central mystery of faith of the Catholic Church and the whole of Christendom)." [[commons:File:WappenScheele.jpg|Coat of Arms]], Bishop [[:de:Paul-Werner Scheele|Paul Werner Scheele]], [[:de:Liste der Bischöfe von Würzburg|Bischof von Würzburg]] 1979–2003. ''See'' [[Ecclesiastical heraldry]].</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=Three+hares&FORM=VIRE8#view=detail&mid=757338BADBA625A33E70757338BADBA625A33E70 |title=Three Hares Window:I visited the 1200 year old University and Cathedral city of Paderborn, the second largest but most beautiful city in the East Westphalia-Lippe region |first1=Thomas |last1=Summer |publisher=Thomas Summer Production/[[YouTube]] |format=video |date=2013-03-17 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> It is viewed as a puzzle, a topology problem or a visual challenge, and has been rendered as sculpture, drawing, and painting.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}
The symbol features three [[hare]]s or [[rabbit]]s chasing each other in a circle. Like the [[triskelion]],<ref name="Widecombe"/> the [[triquetra]], and their antecedents (e.g., the [[triple spiral]]), the symbol of the three hares has a threefold [[rotational symmetry]]. Each of the ears is shared by two hares, so that only three ears are shown. Although its meaning is apparently not explained in contemporary written sources from any of the medieval cultures where it is found, it is thought to have a range of symbolic or mystical associations with fertility and the [[lunar phase|lunar cycle]]. When used in Christian churches, it is presumed to be a symbol of the [[Trinity]]. Its origins and original significance are uncertain, as are the reasons why it appears in such diverse locations.<ref name="Chapman"/>
==Origins in Buddhism and diffusion on the Silk Road== [[File:Three Hares Symbol - Map.svg|thumb|upright=2.2|right|The spread of the three hares symbol between 600 and 1500]] The earliest occurrences appear to be in cave temples in China, dated to the [[Sui dynasty]] (6th to 7th centuries).<ref name="Zhang"/><ref name="travels">[http://idp.bl.uk/archives /news18/idpnews_18.a4d [[International Dunhuang Project]] Newsletter No. 18. ''The Travels of the Three Rabbits: Shared Iconography Across the Silk Road'']. {{dead link|date=April 2012}}</ref> The [[iconography]] spread along the [[Silk Road]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9AUxnUNRekgC&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=Three+hares+running&source=bl&ots=OabnwWDpdO&sig=Xkw0E8V8lwLxDA0AXyV91FiHYQE&hl=en&ei=fAE-TOTQDIK8lQed4_34BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CDEQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Three%20hares%20running&f=false Whitfield, Susan, ''The Silk Road: trade, travel, war and faith'', p. 290.] London: The [[British Library]]. {{ISBN|1-932476-13-X}}; {{ISBN|978-1-932476-13-2}}.</ref> and was a symbol associated with [[Buddhism]].<ref name="Windling"/> The hares have been said to be "A [[hieroglyph]] of 'to be'."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.szasz.com/hare.pdf |title=Staedlin, Naomi, (November 7, 2004) ''The rabbits as a hieroglyph of 'to be'.'' |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-03-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67ArKuuYo?url=http://www.szasz.com/hare.pdf |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> In other contexts the [[metaphor]] has been given different meaning. For example, Guan Youhui, a retired researcher from the [[Dunhuang Academy]], who spent 50 years studying the decorative patterns in the [[Mogao Caves]], believes the three rabbits—"like many images in [[Chinese folk art]] that carry auspicious symbolism—represent peace and tranquility."<ref name="Zhang">{{cite web |url=http://www.threerabbits.net/ |first1=Chris |last1=Chapman |first2=Zhang |last2=Wei |last3=Rasmussen |first3=Peter |title=The Three Rabbits in China |work=Adapted from a presentation at the International Conference on [[Grotto]]es Research |location=Dunhuang China |date=August 2004|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="travels"/> ''See'' [[Aurel Stein]]. The hares have appeared in [[Lotus Flower|Lotus]] motifs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9AUxnUNRekgC&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=three+hares+buddhism+lotus+motif&source=bl&ots=OacjD_KuhK&sig=15xFBOmvWIDFchgL9y9SU8Oblm8&hl=en&ei=DPekTMq_H4KKlwe6hOyZCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCQQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=three%20hares%20buddhism%20lotus%20motif&f=false|title=The Silk Road|work=google.com}}</ref>
The three hares appear on 13th century [[Mongols|Mongol]] metalwork, and on a copper coin, found in [[Iran]], dated to 1281.<ref name="threehares.net">{{cite web | url=http://www.threehares.net | title=The Three Hares | accessdate=2008-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://db.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/hares.shtml |title=Chasing Hares |date=16 November 2004 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2008-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212064007/http://db.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/hares.shtml |archivedate=12 February 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tomgreeves.org/the_three_hares.html | title=The Three Hares | author= [http://www.tomgreeves.org/ Tom Greeves] | accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref>
Another appears on an ancient Islamic-made [[reliquary]] from southern Russia. Another 13th or early 14th century box, later used as a reliquary, was made in [[Iran]] under [[Mongol]] rule, and is preserved in the treasury of the [[Cathedral of Trier]] in Germany. On its base, the casket has Islamic designs, and originally featured two images of the three hares. One was lost through damage.<ref name="meaning">{{cite web |first1=Chris |last1=Chapman |url=http://www.chrischapmanphotography.co.uk/hares/index.html |work=Three Hares Project |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67Asmlqi9?url=http://www.chrischapmanphotography.co.uk/hares/index.html |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |title=What does the Symbol Mean? |df=dmy }}</ref>
One theory pertaining to the spread of the motif is that it was transported from China across Asia and as far as the south west of England by merchants travelling the [[silk road]] and that the motif was transported via designs found on expensive [[Chinese ceramics|Oriental ceramics]]. This view is supported by the early date of the surviving occurrences in China. However, the majority of representations of the three hares in churches occur in England and northern Germany. This supports a contrary view that the three hares occurred independently as English or early German symbols.<ref name="Chapman"/><ref name="Zhang"/><ref name="travels"/><ref name="puzzle">{{cite web | url=http://www.threehares.net/puzzles.html | title=The Three Rabbits and Similar Puzzles | author=Singmaster, David |date = August 2004| accessdate=November 11, 2008| publisher=threehares.net | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918164613/http://www.threehares.net/puzzles.html | archivedate=18 September 2008 | dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Some claim that the Devon name, Tinners' Rabbits, is related to local [[Dartmoor tin-mining|tin miners]] adopting it. The mines generated wealth in the region and funded the building and repair of many local churches, and thus the symbol may have been used as a sign of the miners' patronage.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.legendarydartmoor.co.uk/three_hares.htm | title=The Tinner's Rabbits | author=Sandles, Tim | publisher=Legendary Dartmoor | date=23 November 2007 | accessdate=2008-11-11}}</ref> The [[ornament (architecture)|architectural ornament]] of the three hares also occurs in churches that are unrelated to the miners of South West England. Other occurrences in England include floor tiles at [[Chester Cathedral]],<ref>{{cite web | url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:7gmsuBKphC0J:www.cheshirewestandchester.gov.uk/visiting/heritage/archaeology/idoc.ashx%3Fdocid%3Da1e344d2-e034-4e75-be85-98ed4ece781f%26version%3D-1+three+hares+chester&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgMqXBfw-mvBT3_AZ5KnzDpUjwT5pik-gSyTJI6wpQXn4Od5hI10k54W8sUz9qhk-acrzKxQAWpiY7q1Bq8FQExwnvVsWobptu9pvl3a84IMS8dra-D4mghOq4E-Cch5GefRNTM&sig=AHIEtbRIEWcY1KRQp2amOyhcsuPLrEwDcQ | title=The archaeology of Cheshire West and Chester in ten objects }}</ref> stained glass at [[Long Melford]], Suffolk<ref group=upper-alpha>At the [[Holy Trinity Church, Long Melford]], above the northern door, is a small stained glass [[roundel]], only a few inches in diameter. {{cite web|url=http://www.theukcuriosityblog.com/look/photo/the-three-hares-window-a-medieval-mystery|title=The three hares window: a medieval mystery|date=28 February 2011|accessdate=14 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110918035853/http://www.theukcuriosityblog.com/look/photo/the-three-hares-window-a-medieval-mystery|archivedate=18 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and a ceiling in [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]], Yorkshire.<ref name="Chapman"/>
==In Christianity== The motif of the three hares is used in a number of medieval European churches, particularly in France (''e.g.'', in the [[Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière]] in [[Lyon]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fourhares.com/ |title=Three Hares at Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, four hares, and three hares and three wolves, elsewhere. photographs and drawing |publisher=Fourhares.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-08}}</ref> and Germany. It occurs with the greatest frequency in the churches of [[Devon]], England. The motif appears in [[illuminated manuscripts]],<ref name="|Terrier">{{cite web |url=http://trois-lievres.skyrock.com/ |title=Three hares and their ears commune (''Trois lièvres à oreilles communes'') |first2=Tom (Archaeologist and historian)|last2=Greeves |first3=Sue (researcher)|last3=Andrew |first1=Michel |last1=Terrier |language=French |date=9 September 2007 |accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> architectural [[wood carving]], [[stone carving]], window [[tracery]] and [[stained glass]]. In South Western England there are over thirty recorded examples of the three hares appearing on '[[roof boss]]es' (carved wooden knobs) on the ceilings in [[Middle Ages|medieval]] churches in [[Devon]], (particularly [[Dartmoor]]). There is a good example of a roof boss of the three hares at [[Widecombe-in-the-Moor]],<ref name="Widecombe">{{cite web |url=http://www.widecombe-in-the-moor.com/history/minutes/2005/the_three_hares.php |first1=Tom, Dr. |last1=Greeves |first2=Sue |last2=Andrews |first3=Chris |last3=Chapman |title=From China to Widecombe: The Extraordinary Journey of The Three Hares |publisher=Widecombe-in-the-Moor |accessdate=24 April 2012 |date=26 October 2006}}</ref> Dartmoor, with another in the town of [[Tavistock, Devon|Tavistock]] on the edge of the moor. The [[motif (visual arts)|motif]] occurs with similar central placement in Synagogues.<ref name="Wonnenberg"/> Another occurrence is on the [[ossuary]] that by tradition contained the bones of [[Lazarus of Bethany|St. Lazarus]].<ref name="Shackle">{{cite web |url=http://www.bdb.co.za/shackle/articles/three_hares.htm |last1=Shackle |first1=Eric |work=Eric Shackle's e-book |title=Three Hares Share Three Ears |accessdate=24 April 2012 |year=2006 |location=Sydney, Australia |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67AsPtdXu?url=http://www.bdb.co.za/shackle/articles/three_hares.htm |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
Where it occurs in England, the three hares motif usually appears in a prominent place in the church, such as the central rib of the [[chancel]] roof, or on a central rib of the [[nave]]. This suggests that the symbol held significance to the church, and casts doubt on the theory that they may have been a masons' or carpenters' signature marks.<ref name="Chapman"/> There are two possible and perhaps concurrent reasons why the three hares may have found popularity as a symbol within the church. Firstly, it was widely believed that the hare was [[hermaphrodite]] and could reproduce without loss of [[virginity]].<ref name="meaning"/> This led to an association with the [[Virgin Mary]], with hares sometimes occurring in [[illuminated manuscript]]s and [[Northern Renaissance|Northern European]] paintings of the Virgin and [[Christ Child]]. The other Christian association may have been with the [[Holy Trinity]],<ref name="meaning"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://threehares.blogspot.com/2006/02/why-three-hares_25.html |title=Three Hares as representation of the Trinity |publisher=Threehares.blogspot.com |date=25 February 2006 |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref> representing the ''"One in Three and Three in One"'' of which the triangle or three interlocking shapes such as rings are common symbols. In many locations the three hares are positioned adjacent to the [[Green Man]], a symbol commonly believed to be associated with the continuance of [[Anglo-Saxon]] or [[Celts|Celtic]] [[Christianity and Paganism|paganism]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archaeologyuk.org/ba/ba100/feat5.shtml |title=Green Men & The Way of All Flesh |first1=Richard |last1=Hayma |accessdate=31 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131231951/http://www.archaeologyuk.org/ba/ba100/feat5.shtml |archivedate=31 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> These juxtapositions may have been created to imply the contrast of the Divine with man's [[sin]]ful, earthly nature.<ref name="meaning"/>
==In Judaism== In Judaism, the "[[Rock Hyrax|shafan]]" in [[Hebrew]] has symbolic meaning.<ref group=upper-alpha>In [[Hebrew]], the rock hyrax is called שפן סלע (''shafan sela''), meaning ''rock "shafan"'', where the meaning of ''shafan'' is obscure, but is [[colloquially]] used as a synonym for rabbit in modern Hebrew. {{cite web|first1=Nosson |last1=Slifkin |authorlink1=Natan Slifkin |work=The camel, the hare & the hyrax: a study of the laws of animals with one kosher sign in light of modern zoology |location=Southfield, MI; [[Nanuet, NY]] |publisher=Zoo Torah in association with Targum/Feldheim Distributed by Feldheim |chapter=6 |title=Shafan–The Hyrax |url=http://www.zootorah.com/hyrax/hyrax.pdf |format=PDF |date=1 March 2004 |isbn=1-56871-312-6 |pages=99–135 |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616192614/http://www.zootorah.com/hyrax/hyrax.pdf |archivedate=16 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }} {{ISBN|978-1-56871-312-0}}.</ref> Although rabbits are listed as a non-[[kosher]] animal in the Bible{{mdash}}they at least arguably chew their cud{{efn-ua|Even though they are not a [[ruminant]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://answersingenesis.org/contradictions-in-the-bible/do-rabbits-really-chew-the-cud/ |title=Do rabbits really chew their cud |work=Demolishing Supposed Bible Contradictions |volume=2 |accessdate=June 21, 2017}}</ref>}} lacking [[Cloven hoof|cloven hooves]]{{mdash}}rabbits can carry very positive symbolic connotations, like [[Three Lions (disambiguation)|lions]] and eagles. 16th century German scholar [[Rabbi]] [[Yosef Hayim Yerushalmi]], saw the rabbits as a symbol of the [[Jewish diaspora]]. The replica of the [[Khodoriv|Chodorow]] [[Synagogue]] from Poland (on display at the [[Beth Hatefutsoth|Museum of the Jewish Diaspora]] in [[Tel Aviv]]) has a ceiling with a large central painting which depicts a double-headed eagle holds two brown rabbits in its claws without harming them. The painting is surrounded by a citation from the end of [[Deuteronomy]]:
{{quote| :.כנשר יעיר קינו על גוזליו ירחף. יפרוש כנפיו יקחהו ישאהו על אברתו |Deuteronomy 32:11, [[The Song of Moses]]}}
This may be translated: "As an eagle that stirreth up her nest, hovereth over her young, spreadeth abroad her wings, taketh them, beareth them on her pinions (...thus is [[God]] to the Jewish people)."<ref name="Wonnenberg"/>
The hare frequently appears in the form of the symbol of the "rotating rabbits". An ancient German [[riddle]] describes this graphic thus:
{{quote|<poem>Three hares sharing three ears, Yet every one of them has two.<ref name="Wonnenberg"/></poem>}}
This curious graphic riddle can be found in all of the famous [[wooden synagogues]] from the period of the 17th and 18th century in the [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashknaz]] region (in Germany) that are on museum display in [[Beth Hatefutsoth]] Museum in Tel Aviv, the [[Jewish Museum Berlin]] and The [[Israel Museum]] in Jerusalem. They also appear in the Synagogue from [[Horb am Neckar]] (donated to the Israel Museum). The three animals adorn the wooden panels of the prayer room from [[Unterlimpurg]] near [[Schwäbisch Hall]], which may be seen in replica in the Jewish Museum Berlin. They also are seen in a main exhibit of the Diaspora Museum in Tel Aviv. Israeli art historian Ida Uberman wrote about this house of worship: "... Here we find depictions of three kinds of animals, all organized in circles: eagles, fishes and hares. These three represent the Kabbalistic elements of the world: earth, water and fire/heavens... The fact that they are always three is important, for that number . . . is important in the [[Kabbalah|Kabbalistic]] context".<ref name="Wonnenberg"/>
Not only do they appear among floral and animal ornaments, but they are often in a distinguished location, directly above the [[Torah ark]], the place where the [[Religious text|holy scriptures]] repose.<ref name="Wonnenberg"/>
They appear on [[headstones]] in [[Sataniv]] (Сатанів), [[Khmelnytsky Oblast]], western [[Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mac.com/ruthellengruber/general_site/Sataniv.html |title=Gruber, Ruth Ellen. ''A Tribe of Stones: The Sataniv Cemetery'' |publisher=Web.mac.com |accessdate=2010-03-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67AtZP4eR?url=http://web.mac.com/ruthellengruber/general_site/Sataniv.html |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Gruber, Ruth Ellen |url=http://www.centropa.org/?nID=60&tID=24 |title='The Power of Jewish Headstones.' Traveling in Central Europe |publisher=Centropa.org |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref>
==As an optical illusion or puzzle== {{multiple image | align = | direction = vertical | width = 220 | header = | image1 = Ibbenbueren Dreihasenstein 03.JPG | caption1 = „Der Hasen und der Löffel drei und doch hat jeder Hase zwei.“ (Germany, 1858) | image2 = Musée alsacien-Triquètre aux trois lièvres.jpg | caption2 = „Drei Hasen und der ohren drei und doch hat Keiner mehr ais Zwei.“ (Alsace) | footer = "Three hares, and three ears, and yet no one has more than two." }}
The logo presents a problem in [[topology]].<ref name="puzzle"/> It is a [[strange loop]] rendered as a puzzle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.southwestcrafts.co.uk/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=67_90&products_id=311 |title=Three hares puzzle |publisher=Southwestcrafts.co.uk |date=20 July 2007 |accessdate=2010-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308051243/http://www.southwestcrafts.co.uk/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=67_90&products_id=311 |archivedate=8 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Jurgis Baltrušaitis (son)|Jurgis Baltrusaitis]]'s 1955 ''Le Moyen-Âge fantastique. Antiquités et exotismes dans l'art gothique''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=i-7pAAAAMAAJ&q=lapins#search_anchor Le Moyen-Âge fantastique. Antiquités et exotismes dans l'art gothique] {{ISBN|2-08-081603-9}}; {{ISBN|978-2-08-081603-0}}. p. 134.</ref> includes a 1576 Dutch [[engraving]] with the puzzle given in Dutch and French around the image. It notes:
:The secret is not great when one knows it. :But it is something to one who does it. :Turn and turn again and we will also turn, :So that we give pleasure to each of you. :And when we have turned, count our ears, :It is there, without any disguise, you will find a marvel.<ref name="puzzle"/>
"These are the oldest known dated examples of the Three Rabbits as a puzzle." One commentator believes its being a puzzle is likely reason for the image's popularity.<ref name="puzzle"/>
One recent philosophical book poses it as a problem in perception and an [[optical illusion]]—an example of [[contour rivalry]]. Each rabbit can be individually seen as correct—it is only when you try to see all three at once that you see the problem with defining the hares' ears. This is similar to "The Impossible [[Penrose triangle|Tribar]]" by [[Roger Penrose]],<ref name="puzzle"/> originated by [[Oscar Reutersvärd]]. Compare [[M.C. Escher]]'s [[impossible object]].
==Other uses and related designs== [[File:Wappen Hasloch.png|thumb|Arms of the city of Hasloch]] *The Community of [[Hasloch]]'s [[Coat of arms|arms]]<ref>[[:File:Wappen Hasloch.png|Wappen Hasloch.]] from [https://archive.is/20120803011150/http://www.hdbg.de/gemeinden2/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9677137 source.]</ref> is [[blazon]]ed as: ''[[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]] edged Or three hares passant in triskelion of the second, each sharing each ear with one of the others, in chief a rose argent seeded of the second, in base the same'', features three hares. It is said, "The stone with the image of three hares, previously adorned the old village well, now stands beside the town hall."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hdbg.de/gemeinden2/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9677137 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120803011150/http://www.hdbg.de/gemeinden2/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9677137 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-03 |title=Wappen Hasloch |publisher=Hdbg.de |date= |accessdate=2013-12-08 }}</ref> Hasloch is in the [[Main-Spessart|Main-Spessart district]] in the ''[[Regierungsbezirk]]'' of [[Lower Franconia]] (''Unterfranken'') in [[Bavaria]], Germany.<ref>[http://www.datenmatrix.de/projekte/hdbg/gemeinden/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9677137 Detail on Hasloch].</ref> *Hares and rabbits have appeared as a representation or manifestation of various [[deities]] in many cultures, including: [[Hittavainen]], [[Culture of Finland|Finnish]] god of Hares;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://austinpagan.com/asatru/Finnish-Magic-and-the-Old-Gods.pdf |title=Simon, Terri, ''Finnish Magic and the Old Gods'', The Nomadic Chantry of the Gramarye |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-06-29 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Kaltes-Ekwa]], [[Siberian]] [[Lunar deity|goddess of the moon]]; [[Jade Rabbit]], maker of medicine on the moon for the Chinese gods, depicted often with a [[mortar and pestle]];<ref name="Windling">{{cite web |url=http://www.endicott-studio.com/rdrm/rrRabbits.html |title=The Symbolism of Rabbits and Hares |first1=Terri |last1=Windling |authorlink=Terri Windling |publisher=[[Endicott Studio]] |year=2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67AkEBAkB?url=http://www.endicott-studio.com/rdrm/rrRabbits.html |archivedate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="greathare">{{cite web|url=http://community-2.webtv.net/TheObsidianMask/GreatHare/index.html |title=The Great Hare |publisher=Community-2.webtv.net |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref> [[Ometotchtli]] (Two Rabbits,) [[Aztec]] god of [[fertility]], etc., who led 400 other Rabbit gods known as the [[Centzon Totochtin]]; [[Kalulu]], [[Tumbuka mythology]] (Central African) Trickster god; and [[Nanabozho]] (Great Rabbit,) [[Ojibway]] deity, a [[shape-shifter]] and a [[Creator deity|cocreator]] of the world.<ref name="greathare"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessgenealogy.com/native/tribes/history/nanabozho.htm |title=Nanabozho, Access genealogy |publisher=Accessgenealogy.com |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref> ''See generally'', [[Rabbits in the arts]]. *Tinners' Rabbits is the name of a [[Border Morris]] dance of many forms involving use of sticks and rotation of three, six or nine dancers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breathlessbordermorris.org/Repertoire/TinnersRabbits.pdf |title=Choreography, Tinners Rabbits dance |publisher=Breathless In Berthoud [[Border Morris]] |format=PDF |date= 8 February 2008 |accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weblo.com/music/song/Tinners_Dance/video/734024/3/ |title=Video, Tinners Rabbits dance |publisher=Weblo.com |accessdate=2010-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318164537/http://www.weblo.com/music/song/Tinners_Dance/video/734024/3/ |archivedate=18 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *The hare is rarely used in British [[Armory (heraldry)|armory]]; but "[[Argent]], three hares playing [[bagpipes]] [[gules]]" belongs to the [[FitzErcald]] family of ancient [[Derbyshire]].<ref name="Fox">Fox-Davies, A.C. (1978) [https://books.google.com/books?id=y5tI9jSKxRsC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=FitzErcald&source=bl&ots=sWbCIQA_1b&sig=95yX_iA-DAr3BQaFQCSt2QfDjg0&hl=en&ei=VEJwTK6_CMeNnQf_1ZjKBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=FitzErcald&f=false ''A Complete Guide to Heraldry''] (New York: Bonanza Books) p. 214. {{ISBN|1-60239-001-0}}; {{ISBN|978-1-60239-001-0}}.</ref> Parenthetically, in heraldry the "[[Rabbit|Coney]]", that is the rabbit, is more common than the hare.<ref name="Fox"/> Three coneys appear in the crests of the families: Marton, co. Lincoln; Bassingthorpe co. Lincoln; Gillingham co. Norfolk and Cunliffe co. Lancashire <ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y11BAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT269&lpg=PT269&dq=heraldry+three+coney&source=bl&ots=1REN6Wxn1N&sig=GZyM2yMaSpUmY9Sbss47YAa5Qcw&hl=en&ei=wtBsTo7ZIsX40gHH6YCVBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=1851 |title=Encyclopædia of heraldry: or General armory of England, Scotland, and Ireland |first1=John |last1=Burke |first2=Sir John Bernard |last2=Burke |authorlink2=Bernard Burke |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> *[[Ushaw College]] (St Cuthbert's College, Ushaw) is a Roman Catholic [[seminary]] which includes "Three coneys" in its crest. This adornment is from the family coat of arms of [[William Allen (cardinal)|William Allen]]. *The French crest of the family Pinoteau—dating from the first Baron Pinoteau (1814–1815) and which includes historian [[:fr:Hervé Pinoteau|Hervé Pinoteau]] (former vice president of the [[Académie Internationale d'Héraldique]])—includes three rabbits.<ref>[[:fr:Hervé Pinoteau|Hervé Pinoteau]] French Wikipedia.</ref><ref group=upper-alpha> '''Arms Family Pinoteau''': [[Johannes Rietstap|Rietstap]] gives: Quarterly, 1st silver, a lion [[sable]] armed and langued reds; to 2e gules, a silver sword adorned with gold and 3e gules, a sword of gold band and a rifle gold bars, in saltire; to 4e Silver, a chevron azure, with three rabbits sand stream. Borel Hauterive gives, in the Yearbook of the nobility of France and the royal houses of Europe, T. 21, Paris, 1865: Quarterly, 1st silver, a lion sable armed and langued reds; to 2e gules a sword high silver barons fair district military-3e gules, a sword and a rifle gold necklace set with (weapons of honor) to 4e Silver, a [[Chevron (insignia)|chevron]] azure, three rabbits with sand, which is Brumauld.</ref> ''See generally'', [[Nobility of the First French Empire]]. *Other coats of arms of English and Irish families have three conies or hares.<ref name="Papworth">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6KyIEUzLyR8C&lpg=PA159&ots=pTFrorreMv&dq=three%20conies&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q=three%20conies&f=false |title=Coats of Arms Belonging to Family in Great Britain and Ireland: An alphabetical dictionary of coats of arms belonging to families Ordinary of British Armorials |volume =1 |first1=John Woody |last1=Papworth |authorlink1=John Woody Papworth |first2=Alfred W. |last2=Morant |page=159 |place=London |publisher=T. Richards|year=1874|accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref> *"Three Conies Inn" was the name of a 17th-century inn, and three rabbits feeding was used as a motif on the obverse of its [[Token coin|trade token]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://medievalscotland.org/kmo/Tokens/NumberAnimal.shtml |date=9 February 2009 |title=English Sign Names From 17th Century Tradesman's Tokens |first1=Mari (Kathleen M. O'Brien)|last1=ingen Briain meic Donnchada |publisher=Medieval Scotland,|accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> "The property is believed to date from at least the 17th century; the stone sundial above the former front door shows the date 1622. One of the earliest documented references to the property is an advertisement for the sale of a dwelling in the Northampton Mercury in September 1738. The 1777 Militia List also refers to the 'Thre Coneys'".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thorpe-mandeville.co.uk/three_conies.html |title=Three Conies Inn |publisher=Thorpe-Mandeville yesterday |location=Thorpe Mandeville |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> *Among hunters, a collection of three hares ("a [[brace (sports)|brace]] and a half" or [[wikt:tierce|tierce]])—or three creatures of any kind, especially greyhounds, foxes, bucks—is called "a [[leash]]".<ref>[[Noah Webster]], [http://1828.mshaffer.com/d/word/leash "Leash" Dictionary, 1828.]</ref><ref>[http://east.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/leash "Leash"] [[Merriam Webster]] online.</ref><ref>[http://1913.mshaffer.com/d/word/leash "Leash",] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714123457/http://1913.mshaffer.com/d/word/leash |date=14 July 2011 }} [[Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]], 1913 edition.</ref> *The cover art for [[alternative rock]] band [[AFI (band)|AFI]]'s album [[Decemberunderground]] features three hares, albeit in a different configuration. *The Japanese [[manga]] ''[[Cat Shit One]]'', retitled in the United States as ''[[Apocalypse Meow]]'' focuses on the fate of three rabbit soldiers.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.glenatmanga.com/cat-shit-one-1-9782723456326.htm | title = Cat Shit One No. 01 | work = Manga Glénat | language = French}}</ref> *''Three hares'' are the cover art of a book of poetry by the same name by [[Caroline Carver (poet)|Caroline Carver]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.overstepsbooks.com/cat/three-hares/ |title=Three Hares |first1=Caroline |last1=Carver |authorlink=Caroline Carver (poet)|year=2009 |location=City |publisher=Overstep |isbn=978-1-906856-06-9}}</ref>

The '''two headed alligator''' is a [[Fearsome critters|folkloric animal]] of the [[United States|American]] state of [[Florida]]. Its history is focused mainly within the neighborhood of [[Seminole Heights]] in the city of [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], where it appears on the official seal. It is also the subject of art murals, statues, flags, tee-shirts and other ephemera related to the neighborhood.
== Origins == [[File:Advertisement for North Tampa Pan-Am Garage Seminole Heights history Florida Ave.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for North Tampa Pan-Am Garage Seminole Heights history Florida Ave]] The earliest recorded reference to the two headed alligator was in 1911 when real estate developer, T. Roy Young and his Seminole Development Company purchased 40 acres of land and developed Seminole Heights, Tampa's first suburb. In the promotion of the real estate venture, Young adopted an image of a two headed alligator as part of a neighborhood seal.
A folktale entitled, ''Bite or Smite'', was recorded by R. Perez and A.L. Lopez in 1930 during their research on local superstitions for the [[Federal Writers' Project|Federal Writers’ Project]] of the [[Works Progress Administration|Work Projects Administration]] for the State of Florida. Like many folktales from the region, its characters consist of an anthropomorphic rabbit, alligator and turtle. In the story, the rabbit ignores the warning of the turtle and is eaten by the alligator, who had been concealing a second head. Since it is difficult to date the creation of folklore, it is unclear whether Bite or Smite was the inspiration for, or inspired by, the Seminole Heights seal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://patch.com/florida/seminoleheights/two-headed-alligator-statue-turning-heads-seminole-heights|title=Two-Headed Alligator (Statue) Turning Heads in Seminole Heights|newspaper=Seminole Heights, FL Patch|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-12}}</ref> [[File:Bite or Smite Florida Folklore History Seminole Heights.jpg|thumb|Folktale ''Bite or Smite'' recorded by R. Perez and A.L. Lopez in 1930]]
== 2014 Sighting == In 2014, a man claiming to be a "local naturalist" sent an image of a two-headed alligator he spotted at a Seminole Heights park to the local newspaper, [[Tampa Bay Times]], who ran the image on the cover of the follow day's publication.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2014/07/01/Two-headed-alligator-spotted-in-Florida/5141404226010/|title=Two-headed alligator spotted in Florida?|newspaper=UPI|access-date=2016-10-12}}</ref> As the story became an international headline, scientists started to question the authenticity of the creature. The story was later discovered to be a hoax. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/its-a-total-crock/2186639|title= That photo of a two-headed Seminole Heights alligator? It's a total crock!}}</ref>A local restaurant, [[Ella's Folkart Cafe]], displays a taxidermied two headed alligator that it claims was caught by local trappers soon after the news story.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/46112|title=Tampa, FL - Famous Two-Headed Alligator|website=RoadsideAmerica.com|access-date=2016-10-12}}</ref>
== Statue == In 2016 a Seminole Heights community art fund, [[Urban Art Attack]], funded the building of a 6-foot two headed alligator statue in front of Southern Brewing and Winemaking at 4500 Nebraska Ave.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://patch.com/florida/seminoleheights/two-headed-alligator-statue-turning-heads-seminole-heights|title=Two-Headed Alligator (Statue) Turning Heads in Seminole Heights|newspaper=Seminole Heights, FL Patch|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-12}}</ref> [[File:Seminole Heights Two Headed Alligator Statue.jpg|none|thumb|Seminole Heights Two Headed Alligator Statue]]

{{redirect|Urban Legends|the rock band|Urban Tales|other uses|Urban legend (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|Urban myth|the TV series|Urban Myths}} An '''urban legend''', '''urban myth''', '''urban tale''', or '''contemporary legend''' is a form of modern [[folklore]]. It usually consists of fictional stories, often presented as true, with [[macabre]] or [[humor]]ous elements, rooted in local [[popular culture]]. These legends can be used for entertainment purposes, as well as semi-serious explanations for random events such as disappearances and strange objects.
Urban legends are spread by any media, including newspapers, [[e-mail]] and [[social media]]. Some urban legends have passed through the years with only minor changes to suit regional variations. More recent legends tend to reflect modern circumstances, like the story of people ambushed and anesthetized, who awaken minus one kidney, which was supposedly [[Organ theft|surgically removed]] for [[organ transplant|transplantation]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Mikkelson |first=Barbara |url=http://www.snopes.com/horrors/robbery/kidney.asp |title=snopes.com:Kidney Thief |publisher=''[[Snopes|Urban Legends Reference Pages]]'' |date=2008-03-12 |accessdate=2010-06-30}}</ref>
==Origins and structure == The term "urban legend," as used by folklorists, has appeared in print since at least 1968.<ref>Oxford English Dictionary, 2d ed. 1989, entry for "urban legend," citing R. M. Dorson in T. P. Coffin, ''Our Living Traditions'', xiv. 166 (1968). See also William B. Edgerton, ''The Ghost in Search of Help for a Dying Man'', Journal of the Folklore Institute, Vol. 5, No. 1. pp. 31, 38, 41 (1968).</ref> [[Jan Harold Brunvand]], professor of English at the [[University of Utah]], introduced the term to the general public in a series of popular books published beginning in 1981. Brunvand used his collection of legends, ''[[The Vanishing Hitchhiker|The Vanishing Hitchhiker: American Urban Legends & Their Meanings]]'' (1981) to make two points: first, that [[legend]]s and [[folklore]] do not occur exclusively in so-called primitive or traditional societies, and second, that one could learn much about urban and modern culture by studying such tales.
Many urban legends are framed as complete [[fable|stories]] with [[plot (narrative)|plot]] and [[Fictional character|characters]]. The compelling appeal of a typical urban legend is its elements of mystery, [[Horror (emotion)|horror]], fear or humor. Often they serve as [[cautionary tale]]s.<ref name="Epoch"/> Some urban legends are [[moral|morality tales]] that depict someone, usually a child, acting in a disagreeable manner, only to wind up in trouble, hurt, or dead.<ref name="Epoch">{{cite news |title=Urban legends: Modern morality tales |author=Elissa Michele Zacher |newspaper=''[[The Epoch Times]]'' |date=18 July 2010 |url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/content/view/39382/ |accessdate=29 August 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724140443/http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/content/view/39382/ |archivedate=24 July 2010 |df= }}</ref>
==Propagation and belief== As Jan Brunvand points out,<ref name="Death Car">{{cite web|last= Mikkelson|first= Barbara|url= http://www.snopes.com/autos/cursed/deathcar.asp|title= snopes.com: Death Car|publisher= ''Urban Legends Reference Pages''|date= 2006-08-10|accessdate= 2010-06-30}}</ref> antecedent legends including some of the motifs, themes and symbolism of these [[wikt:urtext|urtexts]] can readily be identified. Cases which ''may'' have been at least partially inspired by real events include "The Death Car" (traced by [[Richard Dorson]] to [[Michigan]], [[United States]]);<ref name="Death Car"/> "the Solid Cement Cadillac"<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.snopes.com/love/revenge/concrete.asp|title= snopes.com: Cement in Lover's Car|publisher= ''Urban Legends Reference Pages''|date= 2006-08-10|accessdate= 2007-07-03}}</ref> and the possible origin of "[[The Hook]]" in the 1946 series of [[lovers' lane | Lovers' Lane]] murders in [[Texarkana, Texas]], United States.<ref>{{cite web|last= Mikkelson|first= Barbara|url= http://www.snopes.com/horrors/madmen/hook.asp|title= snopes.com: The Hook|publisher= ''Urban Legends Reference Pages''|date= 2008-06-02|accessdate= 2010-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last= Ramsland|first= Katherine|url= http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/notorious/texas_chainsaw_massa/5.html|title= Texas Chainsaw Massacre is based on a real case the crime library — Other Speculations — Crime Library on truTV.com|publisher= [[Turner Broadcasting System Inc.]]|accessdate= 2010-08-28|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090831082654/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/notorious/texas_chainsaw_massa/5.html|archivedate= 2009-08-31|df= }}</ref> The urban legend that [[Coca-Cola]] developed the drink [[Fanta]] to sell in [[Nazi Germany]] without public backlash originated as the actual tale of German [[Max Keith]], who invented the drink and ran Coca-Cola's operations in Germany during [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/cokelore/fanta.asp|title= The Reich Stuff? |accessdate= 2007-01-09 |last= Mikkelson |first= Barbara|publisher= ''Urban Legends Reference Pages''}}</ref>
The teller of an urban legend may claim it happened to a friend (or to a [[friend of a friend]]), which serves to personalize, authenticate and enhance the power of the narrative<ref name="believed">Brunvand, p.423</ref> while distancing the teller. Many urban legends depict horrific crimes, contaminated foods, or other situations which would potentially affect many people. Anyone believing such stories might feel compelled to warn loved ones. On occasion, news organizations, school officials and even police departments have issued warnings concerning the latest threat.<ref>{{cite web|last= Gross|first= Dave|url= http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/other/tattoo/|title= The "Blue Star" LSD Tattoo Urban Legend Page|publisher= ''the Lycaeum Drug Archives ''|accessdate= 2010-08-29|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718214538/http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/other/tattoo/|archivedate= 2011-07-18|df= }}</ref> According to the "Lights Out" rumor, [[street gang | street-gang]] members would drive without headlights until a compassionate motorist responded with the traditional flashing of headlights, whereupon a prospective new gang-member would have to murder the citizen as a requirement of [[initiation]].<ref name="Snopes lights">{{cite web|last= Mikkelson|first= Barbara|url= http://www.snopes.com/crime/gangs/lightsout.asp|title= snopes.com: Flashing Headlights Gang Initiation|publisher= ''Urban Legends Reference Pages''|date= 2008-12-08|accessdate= 2010-08-28}}</ref> A fax received at the [[Nassau County, Florida]] fire department was forwarded to police, and from there to all city departments. Even the [[Minister of National Defence (Canada)|Minister of Defence for Canada]] was taken in by the same legend; he forwarded an urgent security warning to all [[Ontario]] Members of Parliament.<ref name="Snopes lights"/>
Many urban legends are essentially extended [[joke]]s, told as if they were true events.<ref>Brunvand, p.223</ref> Urban legends typically include common elements: the legend is retold on behalf of the original witness or participant; dire warnings are often given for those who might not heed the advice or lesson contained therein (this forms a typical element of many e-mail [[phishing]] scams); and the tale is often touted as "something a friend told me", while the friend is identified by first name only or not identified at all.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6090918.stm | work= BBC News | title= Heard the one about... | date= 2006-10-27 | accessdate= 2010-03-28 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090604154846/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6090918.stm | archivedate= 2009-06-04 | df= }}</ref>
Persistent urban legends often maintain a degree of plausibility, such as a [[serial killer]] deliberately hiding in the back seat of a car. One such example since the 1970s has been the recurring rumor that the [[Procter & Gamble]] Company was associated with [[Satan worship|Satan-worship]]pers because of details within its nineteenth-century trademark.<ref>''Procter and Gamble v. Amway'' 242 F.3d 539</ref> The legend interrupted the company's business to the point that it stopped using the trademark.<ref>Brunvand, p.333</ref>
==Belief and relation to mythology== The earliest term by which these narratives were known, "urban belief tales", highlights what was then thought of{{by whom?|date=August 2018}} as a key property: their tellers regarded the stories as true accounts, and the device of the [[Friend of a friend | FOAF]] (acronym for "Friend Of A Friend" invented by English writer and folklorist [[Rodney Dale]] in 1976) was a spurious but significant effort at authentication.<ref>Brunvand, p. 459</ref> The coinage leads in turn to the terms "FOAFlore" and "FOAFtale". While at least one classic legend, the "Death Car", has been shown to have some basis in fact,<ref>Richard Dorson. "American Folklore" University of Chicago Press, 1959, pp. 250-52.</ref> folklorists have an interest in debunking these narratives only to the degree that establishing non-factuality warrants the assumption that there must be some other reason why the tales are told, re-told and believed.<ref name="autogenerated1">Adam Brooke Davis. "[http://missourifolkloresociety.truman.edu/Missouri%20Folklore%20Studies/devilsnight.htm Davis, Adam Brooke. "Devil's Night and Hallowe'en: The Linked Fates of Two Folk Festivals." Missouri Folklore Society Journal XXIV(2002) 69-82] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160305105514/http://missourifolkloresociety.truman.edu/Missouri%20Folklore%20Studies/devilsnight.htm |date= 2016-03-05 }}</ref> As in the case of [[myth]], these narratives are believed because they construct and reinforce the [[worldview]] of the group within which they are told, or "because they provide us with coherent and convincing explanations of complex events".<ref>John Mosier "WAR MYTHS" Historically Speaking: The Bulletin of the Historical Society: VI: 4, March/April 2005.</ref>
Recently,{{when?|date=August 2018}} social scientists have started to draw on urban legends in order to help explain complex socio-psychological beliefs, such as attitudes to [[crime]], [[childcare]], [[fast food]], [[SUVs]] and other "family" choices.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Croft |first= Robin |year= 2006 |title= Folklore, Families and Fear: Exploring the Influence of the Oral Tradition on Consumer Decision-making |journal= Journal of Marketing Management |volume= 22 |issue= 9 & 10 |pages= 1053–1076 |url= |doi= 10.1362/026725706778935574 }}</ref> Here the authors make an explicit connection between urban legends and popular folklore, such as ''[[Grimm's Fairy Tales]]'', where similar themes and motifs arise. For this reason, it is characteristic of groups within which a given narrative circulates to react very negatively to claims or demonstrations of non-factuality; an example would be the expressions of outrage by police officers who are told that adulteration of Halloween treats by strangers (the subject of periodic [[moral panic]]s) occurs extremely rarely, if at all.<ref name="autogenerated1" /><ref> {{cite journal | last1 = Best | first1 = Joel | author-link1 = Joel Best | last2 = Horiuchi | first2 = Gerald T. | title = The Razor Blade in the Apple: The Social Construction of Urban Legends | journal = Social Problems | date = June 1985 | volume = 32 | issue = 5 | pages = 488–497 | issn = 0037-7791 | doi = 10.2307/800777 | jstor = 800777 }} </ref>
==Documenting== The Internet makes it easier to both spread urban legends and debunk them.<ref>Donovan, p.129</ref> Discussing, tracking, and analyzing urban legends is the topic of the [[Usenet]] newsgroup, ''alt.folklore.urban'' and several web sites, most notably [[snopes.com]]. The [[United States Department of Energy]] had a service, now discontinued, called Hoaxbusters, that dealt with computer-distributed [[hoax]]es and legends.
Television shows such as ''[[Urban Legends (TV series)|Urban Legends]]'', ''[[Beyond Belief: Fact or Fiction]]'', and later ''[[Mostly True Stories: Urban Legends Revealed]]'', feature re-enactments of urban legends detailing the accounts of the tales and (typically) later in the show, these programs reveal any factual basis they may have. The [[Discovery Channel]] TV show ''[[MythBusters]]'' (2003–2016) tried to prove or disprove urban legends by attempting to reproduce them using the [[scientific method]].
The 1998 film ''[[Urban Legend (film)|Urban Legend]]'' featured students discussing popular urban legends while at the same time falling victim to them.
Between 1992 and 1998, ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper "Weekend" section published the illustrated "Urban Myths" column by Phil Healey and Rick Glanvill, with content taken from a series of four books: ''Urban Myths'', ''The Return Of Urban Myths'', ''Urban Myths Unplugged'', and ''Now! That's What I Call Urban Myths''. The 1994 comics anthology the ''[[Big Book of Urban Legends]]'', written by Robert Boyd, [[Jan Harold Brunvand]], and [[Robert Loren Fleming]], collected two hundred urban legends told in comics form.
The British writer [[Tony Barrell (journalist)|Tony Barrell]] has explored urban legends in a long-running column in ''[[The Sunday Times]]''. These include the story that [[Orson Welles]] began work on a [[Batman]] movie in the 1940s, which was to feature [[James Cagney]] as the [[Riddler]] and [[Marlene Dietrich]] as [[Catwoman]];<ref>{{cite web |author=Tony Barrell |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/film_and_tv/film/article176017.ece |title=Did You Know: Orson Welles |publisher=The Sunday Times |date=2009-07-05 |accessdate=2012-03-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222142755/http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/film_and_tv/film/article176017.ece |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref> the persistent rumour that the rock singer [[Courtney Love]] is the granddaughter of [[Marlon Brando]];<ref>{{cite web |author=Tony Barrell |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/music/article184306.ece |title=Did You Know: Courtney Love |publisher=The Sunday Times |date=2009-09-13 |accessdate=2012-03-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222142758/http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/music/article184306.ece |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref> and the idea that in a famous 1970s poster of [[Farrah Fawcett]], there is a subliminal sexual message concealed in the actress' hair.<ref>{{cite web |author=Tony Barrell |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/film_and_tv/tv/article186376.ece |title=Did You Know: Farrah Fawcett |publisher=The Sunday Times |date=2009-10-04 |accessdate=2012-03-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222142752/http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/film_and_tv/tv/article186376.ece |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Internet== Internet urban legends are [[folklore]] stories that are spread through the internet. They may be spread through [[Usenet]] or [[email]],<ref name=frost>Chris Frost, (2000) ..Tales on the Internet: making it up as you go along'', Aslib Proceedings, Vol. 52 Iss: 1, pp.5 - 10</ref> or more recently by [[social media]].
===Types=== ;Crime stories :As with traditional urban legends, many Internet rumors are about crimes either fictional, or based on real events but blown out of proportion.<ref>Pamela Donovan, No Way of Knowing: Crime, Urban Legends, and the Internet (Psychology Press, 2004)</ref><ref>Pamela Donovan, ''Crime legends in a new medium: Fact, fiction and loss of authority'', Theoretical Criminology; vol. 6 no. 2; May 2002; Pp. 189-215</ref> ;Chain email letters :[[Chain letter]]s are a variety of urban legends concerning e-mails that tell the reader to make copies of, and redistribute, the e-mail or they will meet a terrible fate.<ref>{{cite web| title=Chain Linked| url=http://www.snopes.com/luck/chain.asp| work=Snopes.com| accessdate=21 November 2012}}</ref> ;Fake virus and malware alerts :[[Virus hoax|Fake virus alerts]], telling people of non-existent threats to their computer, are commonly distributed by email.<ref name=frost/>
===Use in marketing=== The capacity of the internet to spread rumors has been used in marketing, for instance with the low-budget film ''[[The Blair Witch Project]]'', which was advertised as if it were about a genuine urban legend, rather than a work of original fiction.<ref>J. P. Telotte, "The Blair Witch Project Project: Film and the Internet", Film Quarterly, Vol. 54, No. 3; (Spring 2001), pp. 32-39</ref>

{{for|the video game also known as "Vampire Hunter: Darkstalkers' Revenge"|Night Warriors: Darkstalkers' Revenge}} A '''vampire hunter''' or '''vampire slayer''' is a character in folklore and fiction who specializes in finding and destroying [[vampire]]s, and sometimes other supernatural creatures. A vampire hunter is usually described as having extensive knowledge of vampires and other monstrous creatures, including their powers and weaknesses, and uses this knowledge to effectively combat them. In most literature, vampire hunters are simply humans with more than average knowledge about the occult, while they may also be supernatural beings, having superhuman abilities in works of fiction. A well known and influential vampire hunter is Professor [[Abraham Van Helsing]], a character in [[Bram Stoker]]'s 1897 horror novel, ''[[Dracula]]''.
==In folklore== "Professional" or semi-professional vampire hunters played some part in the vampire beliefs of the [[Balkans]] (especially in [[Bulgarian people|Bulgarian]], [[Serb]]ian, and [[Romani people|Romani]] folk beliefs). In [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], the terms used to designate them included ''glog'' (lit. "[[Common Hawthorn|hawthorn]]", the species of wood used for the stake), ''vampirdzhiya'', ''vampirar'', ''dzhadazhiya'', ''svetocher''.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
They were usually either born on [[Saturday]] (then called [[Week-day names#Weekdays numbered from Monday|Sabbatarian]]s,<ref name=summers>{{cite book | last = Abbott | first = George F. | date =1903 | title = Macedonian Folklore | pages = 221–222}}. Cited in {{cite book | last = Summers | first = Montague | origyear = 1929 | title = The Vampire: His Kith and Kin | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fpaCCyGuMqwC&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=Sabbatarian+vampire&source=bl&ots=iAvhmANYfO&sig=HxrVBp2MI0hvnVbk-SeRdKSihP0&hl=sv&ei=6KPOSdvKLoiTsAa8s9mvCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result |date = 2008 | publisher = Forgotten Books | page =36 }}</ref> Bulgarian ''sâbotnichav'',<ref name=dimitr>Димитрова, Иваничка. 1983. Българска народна митология. [http://umotvorenia.bgrod.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=132&Itemid=46 Online article (Bulgarian)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308095558/http://umotvorenia.bgrod.org/index.php?id=132&itemid=46&option=com_content&task=view |date=2016-03-08 }}</ref> Greek ''sabbatianoí''<ref name=summers/>) or the offspring of a vampire and a woman (typically his widow), called a ''[[dhampir]]'' in [[Romani language|Romani]] or a ''vampirović'' in [[Serbian language|Serbian]]. It was also believed that someone born on a Saturday could see a vampire when it was otherwise invisible<ref name=summers/><ref name=dimitr/><ref>{{cite book|author=McClelland, Bruce A.|title = Slayers and Their Vampires: A Cultural History of Killing the Dead|publisher=[[University of Michigan]]|year=2006|pages=62–79|isbn=978-0-472-06923-1}}</ref> (and sometimes other supernatural entities as well); similarly for the ''dhampir''. In the case of the Sabbatarians, it was believed in some places that they needed to be fed meat from a sheep killed by a wolf (Bulgarian ''vâlkoedene''); this would enable them not to fear the things that only they were able to see. In [[Croatia]]n and [[Slovenia]]n legends, the villages had their own vampire hunters that were called [[Krsnik (vampire hunter)|kresniks]], whose spirits were able to turn into animals at night to fight off the vampire or ''kudlak''.
Some carried a kit that used mallet, stake, crucifix. If part of a church it included holy water, holy oil, etc. However the most important things it carried were items such as rope, crowbars, or even pistols.<ref name="dimitr"/><ref>Маринов, Димитър. 1994 (first edition 1914) Народна вяра и религиозни обичаи. [http://www.bulgarian-folklore.com/readarticle.php?article_id=226 Online excerpt (Bulgarian)]</ref><ref name=petr>Петровић, Сретен. 2000. Основи демонологије. In: Систем српске митологије. Просвета, Ниш 2000. [http://svevlad.org.rs/knjige_files/petrovic_mitologija.html#vampir Online (Serbian)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331041243/http://www.svevlad.org.rs/knjige_files/petrovic_mitologija.html |date=2009-03-31 }}</ref>
==In fiction== The vampire hunter has found new popularity in modern fiction and popular culture.
The most widely known example of a vampire hunter is [[Abraham Van Helsing]] of the novel ''[[Dracula]]'' and in other works of fiction adapting or modifying that work. Other more recent figures include [[Buffy Summers|Buffy "the Vampire Slayer" Summers]] from the [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|television show]] and [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (film)|film]] of the same name. Buffy's spin-off series [[Angel (1999 TV series)|''Angel'']] is also focused on a vampire hunter, the titular star, Angel "the World's Champion," a vampire himself, is often portrayed battling vampires. Vampire hunters have also appeared in video games, such as ''[[Castlevania]]'' (occupation of the famed Belmont lineage), and ''[[The Elder Scrolls]]'' (with factions such as the Dawnguard).
As well as being knowledgeable about vampire lore, vampire hunters in fiction are often armed with an eclectic mix of items and weapons which are designed to take maximum advantage of the monster's traditional weaknesses. These have included [[firearm]]s with [[silver]] [[ammunition]], appropriate religious symbols, [[crossbow]]s that fire all wood bolts and even [[watergun]]s filled with blessed [[holy water]] in the movies ''[[The Lost Boys]]'' and ''[[From Dusk Till Dawn]]''.
The organizational strength of depicted vampire hunters can vary wildly. Most hunter characters are in small groups working alone and in secret. By contrast, the [[Hellsing Organization]] in the [[anime]] [[television series]], ''[[Hellsing]]'' is a British government paramilitary strike force with access to troops, heavy combat vehicles and weapons and even allied vampires.
While predominantly depicted as human, examples of other types of vampire hunters also exist. [[Dhampir]]ic figures, having a mix of human and vampire blood, are a popular form. [[Alucard (Castlevania)|Alucard]] from the ''[[Castlevania]]'' series,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gee|first=James Paul|year=2007|title=Pleasure, learning, video games, and life: The projective stance|journal=A new literacies sampler|volume=29|issn=1523-9543|citeseerx = 10.1.1.128.3508 }}</ref> and the [[eponym]]ous hero of the ''[[Blade (comics)|Blade]]'' series of comic books, [[Blade (film series)|movies]], [[Blade: The Series|television series]], and [[Blade Anime|anime]], are both examples of dhampir vampire-hunters. Even rarer are vampire hunters that are vampires themselves. Two examples of this type can be found in [[Morbius, the Living Vampire#Ultimate Marvel|Morbius from ''Ultimate Spider-Man'']], and Zero Kiryuu in the manga and anime series ''[[Vampire Knight]]''.
The image of the vampire hunter is often a mysterious and [[drama]]tic avenging hero, an [[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentric]] [[extremist]], a [[mad scientist]], or sometimes a mix of these. A hunter may be a heroic figure, a villain (from the perspective of the vampire), a lonesome avenger, or sometimes, although not usually, a [[bounty hunter]]-style character, hunting vampires for profit. Vampire hunters have also popularly been depicted as hunting various creatures such as [[werewolves]], [[demons]], and other forms of [[undead]] as well. Others have been depicted as [[Mage (fantasy)|mages]] and [[cyborgs]]. Vampire hunters are often associated with and/or members of the clergy, holy orders, or other religious organizations which may be dedicated to fighting vampires, demons, and other supernatural forces. Vampire hunting as a family tradition or birthright is a popular use of the archetype in fiction, such as the [[List of Castlevania characters|Belmont family]] from the ''[[Castlevania]]'' series. Some hunters devote their entire lives to the eradication of vampires, for others it is just a strange hobby.
Of course with the job for human hunter, comes the risk of getting bitten and turned into vampires themselves. More often than not fellow hunters, usually do mercy killing to prevent them from becoming monsters, though in some fiction it may be possible for a hunter to purify and/or cure themselves (and/or others) of vampirism, especially if the person in question was recently turned into a vampire. Another common trope is hunters being forced to slay their loved ones and/or allies who have been turned into vampires. Alternatively, after becoming a vampire, sometimes hunters will continue to fight and hunt vampires using their newly acquired vampire powers/abilities (sometimes being hunted by their former allies and other human vampire hunters). In addition to human hunters, dhampirs, and vampires that hunt other vampires, it is not uncommon for vampire hunters to be other supernatural creatures such as werewolves or witches. Additionally, some human hunters may possess divine/holy powers, superhuman, and/or other supernatural abilities that they can use both to fight and protect themselves from vampires and other supernatural entities they hunt. Some hunters may even resort to using dark powers/weapons (usually dark magic and/or demonic in nature). Some human hunters may even be tempted to become vampires themselves in order to obtain their powers and immortality, either to continue hunting them, due to fear of their own mortality, and/or simply a lust for power.

{{Infobox journal | title = Vestoj | cover = | editor = Anja Aronowsky Cronberg | discipline = [[Fashion]] | former_names = | abbreviation = Vestoj | publisher = | country = | frequency = Annual | history = 2009-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.vestoj.com/ | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 2000-4036 | eISSN = | boxwidth = }} '''''Vestoj''''' (meaning "clothing" in [[Esperanto]]) is an annual [[academic journal]] about [[dress]] and [[fashion]]. The [[editor-in-chief]] and publisher is Anja Aronowsky Cronberg.
==History== ''Vestoj – the Journal of Sartorial Matters'' was established by [[editor-in-chief]] and publisher Anja Aronowsky Cronberg in 2009. It sets out to "combine theoretical knowledge about fashion with experience from the fashion industry. In the first issue a manifesto was formulated that more than anything was about bridging the gap between fashion as an academic subject of study and fashion as a business".<ref>Falk, Karin, Det Svenska Modeundret, Norstedts, Stockholm, 2011, p. 119</ref> It "stands apart from the current crop of new magazines because of its consciously intellectual stance".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ualresearchonline.arts.ac.uk/3799/ |title=Here is the secret, here is the trick |author=O'Neill, Alistair |work=UAL Research Online |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=March 2011}}</ref> ''Vestoj'' combines scholarly texts about fashion with [[fiction]], [[nonfiction]], [[poetry]], and [[visual arts|visuals]]. Each issue is thematic and its subject matter is reflected in both editorial content and art direction. Every issue consequently has a different logo, style, format, and graphic design. In contrast to the majority of [[list of fashion magazines|fashion magazines]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=David|first1=Alison Matthews|title=''Vogue's'' New World: American Fashionability and the Politics of Style|journal=Fashion Theory|date=21 April 2015|volume=10|issue=1-2|pages=13–38|doi=10.2752/136270406778051049}}</ref> ''Vestoj'' contains no advertising and does not revolve around the fashion seasonal calendar.
==Reception== ''Vestoj'' has been called "one of the most successful attempts to provide the young academic discipline fashion studies with an equivalent to, say, the medical journal ''The Lancet''",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sidbloggen.se/2009/11/24/vestoj-allvarligt-talat-om-mode-pa-esperanto/ |title=Vestoj: Allvarligt talat. Om mode. På esperanto. Och engelska |work=Sidbloggen |author=Wirfält, Johan |date=2009-11-24 |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110053031/http://www.sidbloggen.se/2009/11/24/vestoj-allvarligt-talat-om-mode-pa-esperanto/ |archivedate=January 10, 2010 }}</ref> and journalist [[Fredrik Strage]] labelled ''Vestoj'''s first issue as one of the best new magazines in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sidbloggen.se/titlar/vestoj/ |title=Vestoj |author=Strage, Fredrik |work=Sidbloggen |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2010-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100302042016/http://www.sidbloggen.se/titlar/vestoj/ |archivedate=March 2, 2010 }}</ref> The journal was also described as a publication that "connects intellectual strength and aesthetic refinement"<ref name=interview>{{cite web |url=http://www.anothermag.com/current/view/1384/Anja_Aronowsky-Cronberg |title=An Intellectual Fashion - Anja Aronowsky-Cronberg |author=Grau, Donatien |work=AnOther |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2011-09-28}}</ref> and ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' said that "flicking through ''Vestoj'' gives rise to the same feeling of pleasure that enjoying an old 1950s issue of ''Reader's Digest'': it's engaging, charming, personal and tongue in cheek – without ever compromising the [[intellectual]] quality".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.svd.se/kultur/mode-de-nya-tidningarna_4852911.svd |title=Mode - de nya tidningarna | Kultur |authorlink=Karin Ström |author=Ström, Karin |work=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2010-06-11}}</ref>
In an interview on AnOthermag.com, Aronowsky Cronberg explains her approach, stating that ''Vestoj'' aims to have "an intelligent and multi-facetted approach to sartorial matters. What I find the most interesting methodology is the one that deals with both the production and consumption of a garment, as well as with the analysis of it. […] Through the study of fashion you can understand any given point in history, our desires, ideals, wants and needs. The aspect of fashion that deals with voracious consumption has spread into every way we relate to [[culture]]; today we consume ideas, knowledge and people as much as we consume goods. Fashion in that sense is nothing short of a Gesamtkunstwerk." <ref name=interview />

{{short description|Practice of and belief in magical skills and abilities either alone or in groups}} {{Redirect|Witch|other uses|Witchcraft (disambiguation)|and|Witch (disambiguation)}} [[File:Baldung Hexen 1508 kol.JPG|thumb|upright=0.9|''Witches'' by [[Hans Baldung]]. Woodcut, 1508]] '''Witchcraft''' or '''witchery''' broadly means the practice of and belief in [[magic (paranormal)|magical]] skills and abilities exercised by solitary practitioners and groups. ''Witchcraft'' is a broad term that varies culturally and societally, and thus can be difficult to define with precision,<ref name="Russell">[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=LsjagvvkveEC&oi=fnd&pg=PA2&dq=witchcraft+definition&ots=aw4oz13kOS&sig=2CWBjLB2TIsUt1aNz_nyUPxOf5E&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=witchcraft%20definition&f=false Witchcraft in the Middle Ages], Jeffrey Russell, p.4-10.</ref> and [[cross-cultural]] assumptions about the meaning or significance of the term should be applied with caution. Witchcraft often occupies a religious [[divination|divinatory]] or medicinal role,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and is often present within societies and groups whose [[cultural framework]] includes a magical [[world view]].<ref name="Russell" />
==Concept== [[File:John William Waterhouse - Magic Circle.JPG|thumb|upright|''[[The Magic Circle (Waterhouse painting)|The Magic Circle]]'' by [[John William Waterhouse]], 1886]]
The concept of witchcraft and the belief in its existence have persisted throughout recorded history. They have been present or central at various times and in many diverse forms among cultures and religions worldwide, including both "primitive" and "highly advanced" cultures,<ref>Bengt Ankarloo & Stuart Clark, Witchcraft and Magic in Europe: Biblical and Pagan Societies", University of Philadelphia Press, 2001, p xiii: ''"Magic is central not only in 'primitive' societies but in 'high cultural' societies as well"''</ref> and continue to have an important role in many cultures today.<ref name="ReferenceA">Bengt Ankarloo & Stuart Clark, Witchcraft and Magic in Europe: Biblical and Pagan Societies", University of Philadelphia Press, 2001</ref> Scientifically, the existence of magical powers and witchcraft are generally believed to [[pseudoscience|lack credence]] and to be unsupported by high-quality [[scientific method|experimental testing]], although individual witchcraft practices [[Medical explanations of bewitchment|and effects]] may be open to [[scientific knowledge|scientific explanation]] or explained via [[mentalism]] and [[Psychological theories of magic|psychology]].
Historically, the [[Christian views on magic|predominant concept of witchcraft in the Western world]] derives from [[Old Testament]] [[biblical law|laws]] against witchcraft, and entered the mainstream when belief in witchcraft gained Church approval in the [[Early Modern Period]]. It posits a [[Theosophy (Boehmian)|theosophical]] [[conflict between good and evil]], where witchcraft was generally [[evil]] and often associated with [[Devil in Christianity|the Devil]] and [[Devil worship]]. This culminated in deaths, [[torture]] and [[scapegoating]] (casting blame for human misfortune),<ref>{{cite web|author=Jeffrey Burton Russell |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/646051/witchcraft |title=Witchcraft – Encyclopædia Britannica |website=Britannica.com |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref><ref>Pócs 1999, pp. 9–12.</ref> and many years of large scale [[Witch trials in the early modern period|witch-trials]] and [[witch-hunting|witch hunts]], especially in [[Protestant]] Europe, before largely ceasing during the European [[Age of Enlightenment]]. Christian views in the modern day are diverse and cover the gamut of views from intense belief and opposition (especially from Christian [[fundamentalist]]s) to non-belief, and in some churches even approval. From the mid-20th century, witchcraft – sometimes called contemporary witchcraft to clearly distinguish it from older beliefs – became the name of a branch of [[modern paganism]]. It is most notably practiced in the [[Wiccan]] and modern witchcraft traditions, and no longer practices in secrecy.<ref>[[Margot Adler|Adler, Margot]] (1979) ''Drawing Down the Moon: Witches, Druids, Goddess-Worshippers, and Other Pagans in America Today''. Boston: Beacon Press. pp. 45–47, 84–5, 105.</ref>
The Western mainstream Christian view is far from the only societal perspective about witchcraft. Many cultures worldwide continue to have widespread practices and cultural beliefs that are loosely translated into English as "witchcraft", although the English translation masks a very great diversity in their forms, magical beliefs, practices, and place in their societies. During the [[History of colonialism|Age of Colonialism]], many cultures across the globe were exposed to the modern Western world via [[colonialism]], usually accompanied and often preceded by intensive [[Christianity and colonialism|Christian missionary activity]] ''(see "[[Christianization#Colonial era (16th−19th centuries)|Christianization]]")''. Beliefs related to witchcraft and magic in these cultures were at times influenced by the prevailing Western concepts. Witch hunts, scapegoating, and killing or shunning of suspected witches still occurs in the modern era,<ref>{{Cite news|last=Pearlman |first=Jonathan |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/papuanewguinea/9987294/Papua-New-Guinea-urged-to-halt-witchcraft-violence-after-latest-sorcery-case.html |title=Papua New Guinea urged to halt witchcraft violence after latest 'sorcery' case |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2013-04-11 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> with killings both of victims [[Murder for body parts#Medicine murder|for their supposedly magical body parts]], and of suspected witchcraft practitioners.
Suspicion of modern medicine due to beliefs about illness being due to witchcraft also continues in many countries to this day, with tragic [[healthcare]] consequences. [[HIV/AIDS]]<ref>{{cite web |title=HIV in Africa: Distinguishing disease from witchcraft |date=18 February 2008 |work=thestar.com |url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/columnists/2008/02/18/hiv_in_africa_distinguishing_disease_from_witchcraft.html }}</ref> and [[Ebola virus disease]]<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-28625305 Ebola outbreak: 'Witchcraft' hampering treatment, says doctor], BBC News, 2 August 2014, citing a doctor from [[Médecins Sans Frontières]]: ''"A widespread belief in witchcraft is hampering efforts to halt the Ebola virus from spreading"''</ref> are two examples of often-lethal [[infectious disease]] [[epidemic]]s whose medical care and [[Isolation (health care)|containment]] has been severely hampered by regional beliefs in witchcraft. Other severe medical conditions whose treatment is hampered in this way include [[tuberculosis]], [[leprosy]], [[epilepsy]] and the common severe [[bacterium|bacterial]] [[Buruli ulcer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publichealthinafrica.org/index.php/jphia/article/view/jphia.2011.e10/html_19 |title=Social stigma as an epidemiological determinant for leprosy elimination in Cameroon – Nsagha – Journal of Public Health in Africa |work=publichealthinafrica.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theghana-italynews.com/index.php/component/k2/item/955-ebola-human-rights-group-warns-disease-is-not-caused-by-witchcraft|title=Ebola: Human Rights Group Warns Disease Is Not Caused By Witchcraft|date=3 September 2014|accessdate=31 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903134240/http://www.theghana-italynews.com/index.php/component/k2/item/955-ebola-human-rights-group-warns-disease-is-not-caused-by-witchcraft|archivedate=3 September 2014|df=}}</ref> [[Public healthcare]] often requires considerable education work related to [[epidemology]] and modern health knowledge in many parts of the world where belief in witchcraft prevails, to encourage effective [[preventive healthcare|preventive health measures]] and treatments, to reduce [[victim blaming]], [[shunning]] and [[stigmatization]], and to prevent the [[Murder for body parts#Medicine murder|killing of people]] and [[endangered species|endangering of animal species]] for body parts believed to convey magical abilities.
== Etymology and definitions == {{Further information|Witch (word)}} The word ''witch'' is of uncertain origin. There are numerous etymologies that it could be derived from. One popular belief is that it is "related to the English words wit, wise, wisdom [Germanic root *weit-, *wait-, *wit-; Indo-European root *weid-, *woid-, *wid-]," so "craft of the wise."<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.academia.edu/12416396|title=Power in the Name: The Origin and Meaning of the Word "Witch"|first=Michael|last=Dilts|publisher=}}</ref> Another is from the [[Old English]] wiccecræft, a compound of "wicce" ("witch") and "cræft" ("craft").<ref>{{cite web|last=Harper |first=Douglas|title=witchcraft (n.)|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=witchcraft&allowed_in_frame=0|work=Online Etymology Dictionary |accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref>
In [[anthropology|anthropological]] terminology, witches differ from sorcerers in that they don't use physical tools or actions to curse; their [[maleficium (sorcery)|maleficium]] is perceived as extending from some intangible inner quality, and one may be unaware of being a witch, or may have been convinced of his/her nature by the suggestion of others.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cohn |first=Norman |authorlink=Norman Cohn |title=Europe's Inner Demons |pages=176–9 |date=1975 |isbn=978-0-465-02131-4}}</ref> This definition was pioneered in a study of central African magical beliefs by [[E. E. Evans-Pritchard]], who cautioned that it might not correspond with normal English usage.<ref>{{cite book |last=Evans-Pritchard |first=Edward Evan |title=Witchcraft, Oracles and Magic Among the Azande |date=1937 |pages=8–9 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-874029-2}}</ref>
Historians of European witchcraft have found the anthropological definition difficult to apply to European witchcraft, where witches could equally use (or be accused of using) physical techniques, as well as some who really had attempted to cause harm by thought alone.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thomas |first=Keith |authorlink=Keith Thomas (historian) |date=1997 |title=Religion and the Decline of Magic |pages=464–5 |location=Oxford |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0-297-00220-8}}; Ankarloo, Bengt and Henningsen, Gustav (1990) ''Early Modern European Witchcraft: Centres and Peripheries''. Oxford: Oxford University Press. pp. 1, 14.</ref> European witchcraft is seen by historians and anthropologists as an [[ideology]] for explaining misfortune; however, this ideology has manifested in diverse ways, as described below.<ref name="Pocs">Pócs 1999 pp. 9–10. The first three categories were proposed by [[Richard Kieckhefer]], the fourth added by Christina Larner.</ref>
== Overview ==
=== Alleged practices === [[File:A Witch.jpg|thumb|''A Witch'', 1902, by [[Edward Robert Hughes]]]] Historically the witchcraft label has been applied to practices people believe influence the mind, body, or property of others against their will—or practices that the person doing the labeling believes undermine social or religious order. Some modern commentators{{who|date=April 2011}} believe the malefic nature of witchcraft is a Christian projection. The concept of a magic-worker influencing another person's body or property against their will was clearly present in many cultures, as traditions in both folk magic and religious magic have the purpose of countering malicious magic or identifying malicious magic users. Many examples appear in early texts, such as those from [[ancient Egypt]] and [[Babylonia]]. Malicious magic users can become a credible cause for disease, sickness in animals, bad luck, sudden death, impotence and other such misfortunes. Witchcraft of a more benign and socially acceptable sort may then be employed to turn the malevolence aside, or identify the supposed evil-doer so that punishment may be carried out. The folk magic used to identify or protect against malicious magic users is often indistinguishable from that used by the witches themselves.
{{quote|It is argued here that the medical arts played a significant and sometimes pivotal role in the witchcraft controversies of seventeenth century New England.
